title: Synthetic Recap
body:
NEW YORK — The hardwood floor of Madison Square Garden transformed into a personal stage for Patrick Ewing, as the Knicks’ center delivered a performance for the ages against the Sacramento Kings.

In a commanding 115-101 victory, Ewing was not merely great; he was unstoppable, pouring in a colossal 43 points to lead all scorers. From the opening tip, it was clear the Kings had no answer for his dominant presence in the paint. Ewing’s methodical and powerful offensive display was the engine of the entire New York attack, leaving defenders in his wake and electrifying the home crowd with every turnaround jumper and powerful post move.

While Ewing’s scoring was historic, his backcourt partner Charlie Ward provided the perfect orchestration, dishing out a game-high 14 assists. The Knicks’ offense flowed seamlessly through the duo, with Ward finding Ewing in rhythm time and again. Allan Houston added a crucial 19 points, offering a potent secondary scoring option that kept the Sacramento defense guessing.

The Kings, led by 21 points from Corliss Williamson and 19 from Billy Owens, fought hard but were simply overmatched by Ewing’s singular brilliance. Every time Sacramento threatened to close the gap, Ewing would answer with another bucket, snuffing out their momentum and extinguishing any hope of a comeback.

On this night, the story was written in the stat sheet and etched into the legacy of a legend. Patrick Ewing’s 43-point masterpiece was more than just a winning effort; it was a reminder of his place among the game's elite, a historic night where one man’s will decided the fate of a game beneath the bright lights of the world’s most famous arena.
